title: 103_hr4138
content: OFFSET OF PAST-DUE STATE TAX OBLIGATIONS AGAINST OVERPAYMENTS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow the offset of past-due, legally enforceable State tax obligations against overpayments. Upon receiving notice from a State about a person's tax debt, the Secretary can reduce any overpayment to that person by the amount of the State tax obligation and pay it to the State. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting past-due State tax obligations against overpayments. The Secretary can reduce overpayments by the amount of the State tax debt and pay it to the State. Notifications include the person's details and joint return information. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting past-due State tax obligations against overpayments, including past-due support and legally enforceable debts owed to a Federal agency. The overpayment must be credited to various categories before being applied to past-due support not assigned to a State. The Internal Revenue Code permits offsetting past-due State tax obligations against overpayments, including debts owed to a Federal agency. State agencies must notify individuals of proposed actions and allow 60 days to present evidence before taking action. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting past-due State tax obligations against overpayments, with State agencies required to notify individuals and provide a 60-day period to present evidence before taking action. The term 'past-due, legally enforceable State tax obligation' refers to a debt resulting from specific conditions outlined by the Secretary. The term 'State tax' includes any local tax administered by the chief tax administration agency of the State, which may result from a court judgment or administrative determination, no longer subject to review, or from an assessed but uncollected tax not delinquent for more than 10 years. The Secretary will issue regulations for States to submit notices of past-due State tax obligations. States must include necessary information in the notices. Regulations will specify the minimum debt amount for reduction procedures and allow States to pay a fee for reimbursement. Any fee paid will reimburse the Secretary for applying the reduction procedure. The Secretary will issue regulations for States to submit notices of past-due State tax obligations. States must include necessary information in the notices. Any State receiving notice of an erroneous payment must promptly pay the Secretary an amount equal to the erroneous payment. Additionally, disclosure of certain information to states requesting a reduction under section 6402(e) will be allowed. The Secretary may disclose reduction information to State tax officials upon request under section 6402(e), including whether a reduction was made, the amount, and taxpayer identifying information. State tax officials receiving return information must use it only for agency records or defense in litigation. Amendments are made to sections 6103(p)(3)(A) and 6103(p)(3)(C) of the Code. Section 6402 of the Code is amended to include subsection (e). The Code is amended to include subsection (e) in section 6402, with changes to paragraphs (2), (3), and (4) as well. The amendments made by this section shall have an effective date. The amendments made by this section to section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will apply to refunds after December 31, 1994.
